This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare is $9 to Brindisi.
The combined Sea and special train fare has been reduced to $22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.

During the Monsoon season the express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Thursday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Saturday.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK samp; SON (Egypt) Ltd. - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - CAIRO.
Messrs. HABELDEN samp; Co. - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. samp; O. S. N. Company in Egypt - - - SUEZ.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

div.head: THE SITUATION IN CRETE
div.p:
When the intervention of the European
Powers brought to an end Turkish rule and
Turkish corruption in Crete, and granted a
liberaly measure of autonomy to the islanders,
it was almost universally expected that a few
years would see the union of the island with
the kingdom of Greece. The islanders had
alwys looked forward to such an end. They
had shed their blood not for independence but
for union with Greece, and had endured the
discomforts of a civil war with the Cretan
Moslems and a more or less pacific blockade
by the squadrons of the great Powers, in the
hope that the blue and white flag would
one day fly over their towns. The Powers,
whose action resembled that of a mother
who chastises a child for crying and then
consoles it with sweets and promises, first
fired on the insurgents and then gave
them their autonomy. Their appointment
of Prince George of Greece to the High
Commissionership of the island encouraged the
belief that they not only sympathised with, but
approved of the aspirations of the Cretans.
The autonomous period was naturally regarded
as a brief interregnum to be closed after a few
years by the annexation to Greece of what was
geographically a Greek island. The
Cretan Moslems were mostly converted Greeks,
and those of them who disapproved of the new
Sunlight There is no rubbing and
scrubbing with
Sunlight Soap.
One bar of it, when used
according to directions, will
do more than two bars of
common soap.
Soap
regime solved the difficulty which their con-
tinued occupation of parts of the island might
otherwise have caused by emigrating en masse
to Tripoli or Asia Minor. All seamed favorable
to the early consummation of the islanders'
hopes, but the Powers always prone to make a
fetish of the status quo, did nothing. The
Cretans passed resolutions, and Prince George
put his pride in his pocket and visited one
European capital after another, but all to no
purpose, and on his return found sections of the
population inclined to back their protests by
armed revolution. It being impossible for a
Prince, appointed by the great Powers to
govern the island, to countenance an attempt
to force the hand of Europe by rioting and
bloodshed, whatever his personal sympathies,
not a little of the annoyance which would otherwise have found vent in resoltuions
and speaches, was kept down by his ac-
tion and like confined steam, grew under
pressure. Eventually the explosion came and
a minority led by some able if turbulent poli-
ticians is now encamped on the mountains and
engaged in skirmiches with the British and
Russian troops of the International garrison
and the Cretan police, varied by cattle lifting
and the composition of appeals to the civilised
world in general and Greece in particular.

It is only natural that the Powers should on
principle, resfuse to discuess the Cretian question
till order had been restored. But it is surely
unthinkable that the prestige of Europe would
suffer were the international forces to be with-
drawn, and their place taken by Greeck troops
to whom the insurgents would offer no resis-
tance. The suppression of the rebellion by the
international troops would lead to much
bloodshed and bitterness, would penalise the
whole Cretan people for the misdeeds of a few.
and would solve nothing. The islanders would
remain just as anxious for union with Greece,
the Powers would in a few years have to face
a repition of this summer's disorders, and
Greece would be more and more inclined to
thrown in her lot with the Sultan in the hope of
gaining concessions in Macedonia. Neither
credit nor honor are to be gained against the
Credtan insurgents, and if Greece is not a
strong power that is hardly a reason to
neglect her appeals to be allowed to take
measures for the paciication of the is-
land which she alone could carry out. Prin-
ciple might well give place to expediency
in Crete, and a continuance of the present
policy of the Powers must lead, even if the
present revolt and a score of other revolts
are crushed, to bloodhsed and discontent.
The recent history of the island is a curious
commentary on the results of European in-
tervention, and it is to be hoped that Europe
will at last realise that union with Greece is
the only solution that will ensure a perma-
nent settlement of the Cretan question.

div.head:
ITALIAN CATASTROPHE.
THREE FRESH SHOCKS.
ROYAL GENEROSITY.

div.p:
Three fresh shocks occurred here between 8
o'clock yesterday evening and 2 o'clock this
morning, causing further damage and increas-
ing the panic. The Queen has given £2,000 to place the
poorest of the orphans in an institute, and the
King has also given £4,000 for the sufferers.
(Reuter)

div.head:
THE MIKASA DISASTER
ADMIRAL TOGO SAFE

div.p:
The Mikasa was anchored at Sasebo. The tire started at the base of the main mast and
spread in the most rapid manner, exploding
the magazine nearly an hour after the fire was
discovered. She sank in shallow water and it is
believed that she is repairable. Admiral Togo was not on board. (Reuter)

div.head:
GREECE AND ROUMANIA.
RUPTURE OF DIPLOMATIC-RELATIONS.

div.p:
Diplomatic relations between Greece and
Roumania have been broken off, the latter
having refused to redress various grievances
regarding the Greek subjects in Roumania.
(Reuter)

The attitude of Baron de Rosen in the
negotiations with M. Rouvier on the question
of Morocco has been most friendly and an
agreement is imminent. (Reuter)

div.head:
HUNGARIAN CABINET RESIGNS !
UNIVERSAL SUFFRAGE REFUSED.

div.p:
The Cabinet has resigned owing to the
Emperor's refusal to agree to universal suf
frage. (Benter)

div.head:
THE POPE AND JAPAN.
MISSION bTO THE MIKADO.

div.p:
The American Bishop O'Connell has started
to convey to the Mikado the Pope's congratu
lations upon the magnanimous peace and the treatment of Catholics by Japan. (Reuter)
It is believed that Baron Kamnra is suffering with typhoid fever. A specialist has been Bummoned, end his return has been postponed indefinitely. M. Takahira remains with him.
(Reuter)

The Russian peace commissioners have sail
ed. Baron Kamura starts on Thursday despite
his illness.
(Reuter)

div.head:
STRIKERS AT LONGWY
A BELGIAN KILLED

div.p:
In a demonstration of strikers a dragoon
killed an agitator of Belgian nationality. (H.)

div.head:
THE FRENCH PRESIDENT
VISIT TO LISBON

div.p:
Mr. Loubet will go to Lisbon on his way
back from Spain. (Havas)
The politician M. Goblet is dead. (Reuter)
M. Goblet has died. (Havas)

The St Leger Stakes. 1. Challacombe; 2.
Polymelus ; 3. Lees O'Glory.

div.head:
THE CAUCASUS TROUBLE.
PRINCE NAPOLEON
APPOINTED GOVERNOR.
INCENDIARISM AT BAKU.

div.p: >Prince Napoleon has been appointed Governor of. the Caucasus. (Haeas)

Firing continues in the outskirts and incen
diarism and plunder are rife at-Balakhany.

Many factories in the Volg provinces are
already dosed for want of fuel (Renter)

div.head: CRESCIT EUNDO—
div.p:
M. Avram Romano has
been authorised by the Sanitary Department
to practise as a pharmacist in Egypt.

div.head: STRAY AND OWNERLESS DOGS
div.p:
found in the
Boulao district of Cairo daring to morrow night
and at dawn of the 16th inst. will be poisoned by the police.

div.head: SUEZ CANAL.—
div.p:
10 vessels passed through
the Canal on the 11th inst, 7 of which were
British, 1 German, 1 French, 1 Austrian. The
days receipts were frs. 330,371.94, making the
total from the 1st inst frs. 3,193,305 51.

div.head: HASHISH SEIZURES —
div.p:
The Alexandria police
seised a sack yesterday containing 21 turbas of
hashish, and on Tuesday. the police of Cairo
seized 31 kilogrammes of that contraband,
which they found in a house in the Esbekieh
quarter.

div.head: THE CAIRO AMERICAN MISSION. —
div.p:
The
services in English in the Church of the
American Mission, Cairo, will be resumed on
Sunday evening next at 6 o'clock. Residents and
visitors are most cordially invited to join
in these-services.

div.head: A CORRECTION.—
div.p:
Sheikh Mohamed Shakir,
Chief of the Ulema at Alexandria, has protest
ed in a letter published by the "Mokattam"
against the statement in that paper that the
relations between him and the Sheikh el
Sherbine have recently been strained

div.head: LAND SALES.—
div.p:
We are informed that Mr.
Khoury, manager of the Land and Mortgage
Co. of Egypt, who recently boaght 12 feddans
of land near the Mahmoudieh Canal for L E.
30,000 has resold the site for L.E. 40,000 to
certain buyers, who hope to ba able to sell
again at a still higher figure.

div.head: SAN STEFANO CASINO. —
div.p:
The farewell vocal
concert will be given at the San Stefano Casino
at five o'cloak this evening. On Sunday next at 10-30 a.m the-usual concert will be given-by the Bracale orchestra. A concert will also be given on Sunday afternoon from 5 to 8 p.m. by the Greek Philharmonic Band. A children's entertainment was given yesterday afternoon in the hall of the casino, when a large number of young people attended and enjoyed immensely (the representation of Cendrillon en Miniature^ the pupils of Professor Longhi, which demonstrated both the teaching capability of the professor and the zeal of his young pupils.

div.head: To AID THE SUFFERERS. —
div.p: We are glad to learn-that in Cairo, as in Alexandria, steps are being taken to swell the funds for the relief the thousands who have suffered so terribly by the recent earthquake that devastated a great part of Calabria. A contemporary announces that the proceeds of a special performance to be given by the Italian Philodramatio Society, on the occasion of the anniversary of the entry of the royal troops into Rome, will be devoted to that -purpose and also that a performance with a similar aim will be given at the Egyptian Theatre. We again express our hope that Alexandrians will generously support the benefit representation at the Alhambra Theatre on Monday evening, when Come le Foglie and Meglio soli che male accompagnati will be, staged by the Delia Gaarda Dramatio Company.

div.head: THE WEATHER IN CAIRO. —
div.p: A most welcome change in the weather has taken place in Cairo during the last few days. The heat, which was so intense, and at times almost unbearable, during July and August, has considerably diminished, and the morn-ings and evenings now are delightful: Residents who have been obliged to pass the summer in that city will have just cause to remember it, for the summer-now coming to a dose has been one of the hottest and most trying on record, the thermometer in several instances having been up as high as 114° Fahrenheit in the shade between noon and 8 o'clock. It has now fallen to 90° Fahrenheit at the hottest time of the day, but at night the temperature is no more than 60° Fahrenheit. The great heat of the past two months caused a perfect exodus from Cairo to San Stefano, Port Said, and Ras El Bar; at the letter plase the number of visitors this season has been double what it was last year.

div.head:
IRRIGATION.
TRANSFORMATION. PROGRESSES
div.p: The Projects Circle of the Irrigation Depart- ment has almost completed its transformation of the "basin" system to that of perennial irrigation in Beni Suef province. The officials of this circle will next year remodel the irrigation tian system of Gizeh province and by 1907 the whole of Upper Egypt frill enjoy the benefits of perennial irrigation.

In Lower Egypt the system of perennial irrigation's supreme except in a few limited areas, and in these the remodeling will not take more than twelve months to complete. In three years' time, therefore Egypt will possess a complete system of perennial irrigation, to the great advantage of landowners and of the country in general.

div.head: THE TELEPHONE COMPANY
div.p: The State Telegraph Department are about to lay for the company two new cites lines between Cairo and Alexandria which, when completed next year, will greatly relieve the present pressure on the two lines that have been now in use for three years. There will also be -another line between Cairo and Tantah, and Alexandria and the latter- place so that in future messages can be transmitted | direct between the two cities and Tantah. Part of the work on-this line has been finished, and the remainder will be completed as soon as the necessary grant has been obtained by the Telegraph Department We are informed that, should the new service to Tantah prove a commercial success there is every probability that the system will be extended to important towns, such as Zagazig, Por Mansourah, and, perhaps, Suez.

div.head: THE HELOUAN RAILWAY.
div.p: As we mentioned a short time ago, it has been decided to double the line between Bab-el-Louk and TouraL The engineers of the company are at present busily engaged ba the work, and the laying of the second line of rails will be taken in hand early in the new year, when the neceesary material twill have arrived. Four new first-date-Car- riages on the corridor system, and similar to those in use on the State Railways are ex- pected from Europe in November. It is also (intended to improve all the stations on the line. There is no truth in the rumour that the Heltuan Railway has lately purchased a large plot of land at El Maadi, one of the |lstations, with the intention of re-selling it in small plots for building purposes.

div.head: THE LATE MOG PASHA.
div.p: The funeral service for tire late Mog Pasha took place at 9 a.m. morning at St. Caffcerine's CathedraL Among those present were H. E. Ali Bey Sadik, Sub-Governor of Alexandria, representing the Regent with the Consuls and several representatives of the Caisse de la Dette.

The family of the late Mog Pasha tenders its thanks to those who were present at the funeral service this morning, to those who sent wreaths and to all who have shown their sympathy on the sad occasion.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The More liner Seti sailed yesterday after noon for Liverpool, via Malta, with passengers, mails and general cargo.
The M.M. mail beat Senegal, which left Alexandria last Friday, arrived at Marseilles on Tuesday evening.

The Russian Steam Navigation Company's S.S. Emperor Nicholas II. will leave Alexandria on Wednesday next for Odessa and will touch at Pireaus, Smyrna, Daranelles, and Constantinople. The steamer will also connect directly with the same company's mail boats for Sevasterpool, the Anatolian, Caucasian, Crimean, and Sea of Azov ports.
The S.S. Spartan Prince, from Antwerp and London, with passengers and general cargo, left Malta yesterday, and is due to arrive at Alexandria on Sunday.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: The Sirdar, Major-General Sir Reginald Wingate, accompanied by Lady Wingate, will leave London on the 26th inst. for Egypt
Mr. Cecil Higgins, third secretary to H.B.M's Agendy/ has left for Europe-
Chitty Bey, director-general of Customs, arrived yesterday at Alexandria from Cairo.
Captain Adams, general manager of the Delta Light Railways Company, will arrive in Cairo from Europe about the 10th October.

The Reverend Rowland Wormell, M.A. assistant chaplain of St Marks, Alexandria and All Saints' Ramleh, has been nominated by the Secretary of State to the Indian ecclesiastical establishment of Bombay! MA Wonnell will proceed to Bombay per P. and 0. steamer about the middle of November
The A.C.C. is giving an "at home" tomorrow to the officers of the 2nd Royal Berkshire Regiment, on the occasion of the matels between the Regimental XI. and the A.C.C.

div.head:
CIGARETTE TRADE OF EGYPT
EXPORTS GREATLY INCREASED.
div.p: As most of our resident readers are aware the cigarette trade is one of the most important and flourishing industries in this country, and it bar been remarkably developed daring the last few years? The export portion of the trade is the one that has been more steadily Increasing in volume and, judging by the customs return* the^increase has lately been augment-ing by leaps and bounds. Last year the total experts amounted approximately to 500 million cigarette weighing over 650 tons, whilst the previous year's total of the cigarettes exported from Alexandria, Port Said, and Suez was about 400 million so that there was an increase of one year of no less 100 millions. As shown by these customs returns, during the past quinquennial period the business of the five leading firms of manufacturers has increas- considerably, and compared with, say fifteen or twenty yean ago, there Law beer an enor- mous development in the which cigarette trade and a consequent augmentation in the number of all manufacturers. Of the total-exports one Cairo firm alone exported 134 million cigarettes, the whole of which went to Germany and was of the cheaper description. Another well-known Cairo firm comes next with art ex- port of 110 millions, a large portion of which went to the United Kingdom and was composed mostly of the dearer and better class of cigarettes. Almost the whole manufacturing trade is done in Cairo on account of the dryness of the dimate and its consequent suitability. From the returns that have been furnished by the customs of that city the exports during the past four years have been as follows in round figures;

Of the total expert from Egypt of £20,476 kilos, valued at slightly over £500,000, Germany took about one half, whilst the United Kingdom comes next with close on 100,000 kilos, valued at £80,000. In these last figures we do not include the quantities exported to British possessions or colonies, which latter took 75,500 kilos, worth £59,700. As we mentioned in an article published a few days ago the exports to the United States of America, compared with that of other countries, are very small on account of the vexations restrictions imposed by the American Customs.

Out of the total export trade from Egypt of 620 metric tons, Port Said stands as the head of the ports of embarkation. It exported some 307 tons, valued at L.E. 246,000; Alexandria exported some 224 tons, of a value of L.E. 180,000 and Suez about 88 tons valued at L.E. 69,000. Of the 307 tons from Port Said, 42 tons went to the United Kingdom, 194 tons to Germany and 11 to the Far East. The average wholesale export price of Egyptian cigarettes appears to be about 7s. 6d. or 9.50 francs per lb.

The manufacturers complain that their trade suffers at present under a great disadvantage, in that they have to pay an import duty of P.T. 20 on every killogramme imported, and recieve a drawback on exports of half the amount, which they consider unjust, as under the customs tariff now in force they have to pay the same amount o duty on cigarettes, whether they are consumer in the country of out of it. They therefore contend that the ciggarete manufacturered expressly for exportation should be except of duty altogether, and offered some time ago to erect bonded ware houses for the manufacture of the goods intendd for export in bond. So far the Customs authorities have not entertained, or rather given their consent to this arrangement, but should they at any future time saction it, there is no doubt that the adoption of such a system would give a further great stimulus to the cigarette industry of Egypt, and Cairo in particular.

We may remark, on passant, that the designation of the cigarettes made in this country as Agyptian is a misnomer, as the tobacco comes almost entirely from Turkey, as most people are aware, and the paper used in rolling the cigarettes is importaed from Austria principally.

A small quantity of the tobacco comes from the district of Xanth, in the province of Thrace; and the export is almost entirely from Cavally, where the leading manufacturers of Cairo and Alexandra possess large depots, containing, at times, many thousands the cigarettes being now exported to ever civlized part of the globe - from Noway to Capy Colony, from to the West Coast of Africa, and to every country on the continent of America, as well. Besides a huge local export trade, some of the leading firms supply as well athe tobacco regies of France, Italy, and Austria.

div.head: NEW FACTORIES IN PROSPECT
div.p: New indsutrial concerns are springing up on Limasol, where the commerical spirit is more presence than in other parts of the island. The brick and file factory to which reference whas shade in these notes on further occasion and which has been a very long times making its preparation is ready, so i understand to communicate ...

div.head: AGRICULTURAL NOTES.
div.p: Good sales of Cyprus barley to England have lately been affected and considerable shipments have also been made to France, Morocco, and other countries. A large quantity of fruit have been destroyed again this year hornets, and louests are reported to have done some damage to certain crops.
The following are among the leading exports from Larnecia to Egypt during August:

div.head: PERSONAL.
div.p: Miss Biddulph, sister of Lady King Harman, and who has been staying in Cyprus since last autumn, is about to return to England, together with His Excellency's two sons who have been spending their summer hundays here. Mr. Lewis Biddulph, of the Bank of Egypt, Khartoun, Lady King Harman's brother is now on a visit to Government Cottage Troodos. Mr. Chaouls, Manager of the Imperial Ottoman Bank, Damascus, and his wife and family have been spending some weeks in Cyprus.

div.head: A CASE OF RABIES.
div.p: A case of rabies occured last week. Hithero this disease among dogs is thought not to have existed in Cyprus.

div.head: THE WEATHER.
div.p: The severe and very trying spell of damp heat which we were experiencing last week has passed, and since Sunday we have been blown about by an almost incessient rain producing most unpleasant dust, but cooling and drying in its effects. At Limassol a vessel laden with carobs ran aground off the central front of the town, and the discomfort of intense, enervating heat was much aggravated by the abominable and given off by the rotting vegetables. It has propsed to try and blow the ship with dynamite.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA SWIMMING CLUB
div.p: The usual weekly meeting of the Alexandria Swimming Club was held last Saturday when the attendance numbered sixteen, including juniors.
There where some good diving exhibitions by several members of the club, and this was followed by a water polo practice match.
The club will meet on Saturday next at Custon Gate No. 23 as usual.

div.head: ESBEKIEH GARDENS.
div.p: By kind permission of Lieut. Colonel R. C. C. Cox commanding and Officers 2nd Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers the Band will perform the following programme in Esbekieh Gardens to morrow, Friday, evening, commencing at 9 o'clock.

div.head: EGYPTIAN SHARE MARKET.
div.p: Several important events have taken place since last week, all of which have affected the values of Stock Exchange securities: First and in foremost the full Treaty of Perice, consisting of seventeen articles, was finally signed on d. Tuesday, the 5th instant and although this He has caused a good deal of dissatisfaction in Tokio, resulting in disturbances of quite serious nature, more so than was anticipated to by the friends of Japan, still there is no doubt is that the ratification of the treaty by the res pective Emperors, will take place well within e the time stipulated.
Secondly, the direo ors of the Bank of 11 England decided at their meeting yesterday. to raise the rate to 3%, and notwithstanding dome of the leading dealers in the Stock Ex
change thought this rise might have been d delayed for a weak further, the city, as soon as fit knew that another three-quarters of a million

overeigns had been withdrawn from the Bank tfor South America, was quite glad that the matter was settled. It is evident that both South America and Egypt will require a t considerable sum of gold this autumn, and in addition there is the possibility of gold being taken for the United States. The announcement at 12 o'clock of the directors' decision produced little effect on prices. Consols opened at 90 and relapsed to 90, but leave off to-day. at 90

Thirdly, there was the final settlement of the difficulty between France and Morocco, which at one time had a serious aspect, but by the Sultan's acceptance of all the demands of France this is now ended. Lastly, the recent reports which have come to hand from the Caucasus show that the Tartar insurrection at Baku is proving to be very alarming. The destruction of the petroleum industry had, of bourse, a serious effect on all the petroleum shares here, many millions of which are held by English investors.

During the earlier part of the week there was quite a small boom in almost all markets, but this has not been maintained, and yester day there was a distinct feeling of depression throughout the stock markets in general, Japanese bonds, which have been selling pretty freely, especially by America, fell to The new loan closes to-day at 31 premiam, Russians on the trouble in the Caucasus, declined but close at 944 Copper shares have been flat on the further fall in raw material, Tintos leaving off at 668. The American railway market has also been weak, owing to a heavy bear attack in Wall Street. The reaction in New York in the opinion of some, due to the extraordi nary productions of Mr Lawson, which have been appearing in the English and American Press

Egyptian stocks, after improving with other markets early in the week, have eased off again. National Banks are down to 28. Agri cultural Bank to 141, and Daira Sanieh shared to 274. Daira sugar have improved with more support from Paris. At the beginning of the week they went up to 4, but they have dropped back now and close 4 buyers. In as much as all the debentures have been paid off and the Company have a lien in all the sugar factories in Egypt, these shares should be worth attention.

It is persistently rumoured in Paris that syndicate is being formed under the auspices of Sir Ernest Cassel to take over all the remaining assets of the Sucreries et Rafinerie d'Egypte. We give this with all reserve, but Sir Ernest Cassel, for several reasons, more especially that of his still having large interests in Egypt, would naturally be desirous of takin care of the Egyptian sugar interests much as possible. He is still in Paris where been for some days past. The idea here i that some arrangement will be come to by which the Daira Sugar Company will absorb the Sucreries et Raffinerie d'Egypte.Steps have already been taken in Egypt, as reported in our last, to protect the interests of the Share holders and in the event of the Court agreeing to a liquidation we understand Sir Elwin Palmer and Harari Pasha will be appointed Liquidators. The shares of the, Sucreriee d'Egyp'e are quoted in Paris to-day at 54 francs. The mining market in the early part of the week showed distintight of fevival, all the leading African shares having a considerable rise. Consequently Egyptians exhibited a certain amount of responsiveness, although dealings in this market were on a small scale! Nile Valleys, while not so high as they have been, were well supported at 15/18. Egyptiah Mines Exploration stock is firm at 14:3. Good reports of development in the Semra mine of the above are to hand. The reef in No! 1 shaft has given assays of 1 ounce 9 dŵth: over a width of 86 ins and in No! 2 shaft 1 ounce 16 dwts over 42 the This is lockedupon very favorable as showing good capabilities in the near future.
Khedivial Mail Steamship Co.'s shares have somewhat reacted from the higher price of last week and are how quoted at 17.0.

div.head: UNE MOSQUEE A PARIS
div.p: Les demarches d'un Egyptien

Un Francis 6tabli an Cairo depuia de nom brouses anuses, M. L. Lambert, a pris l'initia- tive de feire demarches aar demarches poor fairo aboutir le projet de la creation d'une moaqude à Paris. A on journaliate qui eat alld le voir M. Lam bert a fait, aveo beanooap d'amabilita, les ds olarationa suivantes: — Je 8oia vena expr8 à Paris poor aoa mettre an gouvemement fran^aia cette inures aante question, dont lea consequences politi ques seront enormes. J'ai eu une longue conference hier aveo on bant fonotionnairo do ministfcre des oultes, qui a fait le meilleur acoueil à mon projet et ma conaeilie de m'adresser au miniatro dee affaires £trangsres pour quo oeiui-ci entamat des negooiations aveo la direction des domaines afin de trouver à Paris un terrain convenable dont la concession nous permettrait d'edifier la moaqude taut dsirde. Il y a quelques jours je m'etais Igalemeut rendu au minUtro de l'interieur qui a tranamis depuia le dossier contenant vingt un documents rolatifs à cette demande de concession. Ces documents sont aignds par les quatre grands cheikba de 1'University d'El-Arhar, c'eat-k-dire par les personnages lea plus influents du monde musulman. L'an d'eax, Abd-el-Rahman-el-Maleky (Maro- oain), qui eat trss influent non seulement en Egypte, maia en Alg6rie et aurtout au Maroc, son pays d'origine, oil je vais me renoontrer avec lui dans quelques joare et lui fairo part du rsultat qu'auront donnd mes demarches, et qui sera aocompagn^ par son neveu, le fils d'Abd-el-Kader, approndrait aveo une joie sincere que la France a aooaeilli favorablement notre requete. Le oheikh Abd-el-Rahman-el-Maleky m'avait manifesto le dsir de venir à Paris pour m'aa aiater dans mes demarches, et oela aurait trsa certainement 4t4 du meilleur effet, mais au dernier moment il n'a pu aooomplir ce voyage. Mais j'eapdre que le gouvemement frangai ne voudra pas tarder plus longtemps à prondro une decision, puisque depuis de nombrouses I ann^es des mosqudes ont 6t6 4difi6es à Londrea et à Berlin par lea soins des gouvemements | anglais et allemand. Le prestige de la France aurait tout à gagner I à pareille decision: l'abandon de l'Egypte à ['Angleterre a cr6y obez les musulmans un | cbeux ytat d'esprit à notre dgard. Vo ilk quarante-trois ans que j'habite le Cairo, I j'avais accompagnd M. de Lesseps; j'ai do aombreuses relations en Egypte, et tous les musulmans avec lesquels j'ai eu l'oooasion de n'entrotenir m'ont toujours dit: Comment so ait-il que la France, pays bospitalier et g4n6 ' reux, ne fasse rien pour nous 1 Eh bien I le moment est venu, les fonds n6 ceaaairoa à l'yreotion d'une mosqu6e à Paris et aussi à Marseille — oh se trouvent de nom breux musulmans — sont prdts. De divers cdtds j'ai re$u en effet des offres de conoours gyndreux et j'ai pu fairo parvenir au miniature de l'intyriear les listes de soascription, dont le nombre s'augmente cheque jour. Le sultan de Tutquie, le Khydive d'Egypte et plusieurs princes, princesses, paches et riches musulmans ne manqueront paa de participer à cette oeuvre, jen suis con vain on. Les chefs roligieux de l'lslam n'ont paa mar chandy, en plus d'une oiroonstanoe, les nom breuses concessions de terrains aooord4es aux congrygations religieuaes, et la France en a obtenu une large part. (Test bien le moins que le dysir legitime dea musulmans soit pris en considyration. Nous avons tout à gagner, oar l'Allemagne nous sup- plan te chaque jour davantage dans l'influence que nous avons tonjoars possydye auprks des disciples de Mahomet, qui oependant nous ai ment toujours. Je vais fairo dresser les plans de la future mosquye, qui ne sera autre chose qu'un oara- vansyrail comprenant one yoole et une salle do union. — Oh s'yihvera cette mosquye t — Probablement prks des Invalides ; mais d'ici pen j'espkre £tre flxy à oet ygard. Boyer persuady que, le jour oh Paris aara sa mosquye, les musulmans y viendront volontiers et en grand nombre: ils a'y sentiront mieux ohtz eux.

div.head: Tribunal Consulaire d'Italie
div.p: Le tribunal consulaire d'Italie a condamny le constable Alessandrello, anoien agent de la police secrkte da kism de la place, à un an e demi de delusion poor avoir biesay d'un coup de revolver un italien dans un cabaret de U rue des amors. Le tribunal a condamny le frkre du SUB nom my Giuseppe Alessandrello à 79 jours de prison et Grimaldi qui a donnd l'hospitality k Alessandrello à 25 jours de la m4me peine.

div.head: Aux Sucreries
div.p: M. A Ninci vient de donner sa demission de directeur commercial qu'il occupait depuis quelques mois a la societe des sucreries ou son avancement avait ete des plus rapides. Sa demission a ete immediatement acceptee. Un employee de la Banque Nationale est appelle a la remplacer.

div.head: Funerailles
div.p: La familee Mog Pacha se fait un devoir de remercien toutes les personnes qui ont bien voulu assister aux funerailles de S.E. og Pacha, ainsi que celles qui ont envoye des couronnes, ou qui lui ont temoigne leur sympathic dans cette douloureuse circonstance.

div.head: SUDAN LAND SETTLEMENT.
div.p: NEW ORDINANCE.

Whereas it is expedient to make special pro- vision for the settlement of claims to waste forest and unoccupied lands, It is hereby enacted as follows :— 1—This Ordinance may be called "The Land Settlement Ordinance, 1905." 2. —In this Ordinance the word "land" in-cludes benefits to arise out of land and things attached to the earth or permanently fastened to anything attached to the earth. The words "unoccupied land" include uncul- tivated land and all land which shall not have been in the uninterrupted occupation of some person or persons for a period exceeding five years next before a notice given by the Governor General with reference to such lands under the next section, and also all lands which, owing to their height above the river, the infrequency of rains, and other circum- stancee, have been cultivated at irregular intervals only. 3. —(i.) Whenever it shall appear expedient to the Governor General to effect a settlement of claims in or over any lands which are or are alleged to be waste, forest, or unoccupied, he shall publish a notice in the "Sudan Qszatte," (a) specifying as nearly as possible the situation and limits of such land. (6) declaring it is proposed to effect a settlement of such land. (,•) appointing an Officer (hereinafter called the Settlement Officer) to inquire into and determine the existence nature and rights claimed by or alleged to exist in favor of any person in or over any land comprised within such limits and to deal with the same as provided in this Ordinanoe. (ii.) The Governor General may at any time by a notice in the ' Sudan Gazatte" annul the appointment of any Settlement Officer or appoint another Officer in his place. 4. —When a notice has been published under section 3 the Settlement Offioer shall publish in Arabic at the offices of the Governor of the Province and the Mamur of the district and at convenient places in the neighbourhood of such land a proclamation. (a) specifying as nearly as possible the situation and limits of the land which it is proposed to settle. (6) fixing a period within which any pereon claiming any right in or over snch land is required to present to such Officer a written notice specifying the nature of such olaim. 5. —(i) After the expiration of the period specified in section 4 the Settlement Officer shall hold enquiries at convenient places on or near the land which it is proposed to settle. 8uch reasonable notice as may be possible of the date and place of such enquiries shall be given to the claimants. The Settlement Officer shall enquire into all claims made under section 4 and the existance of any right or practice in or over the land in respect of which no claim has been made and shall record a summary of his enquiry in writing. (ii.) And after hearing the claimants or their dnly authorised agents if they present themselves the Settlement Officer shall adjudicate upon every claim. 6. —(i.) If the Settlement Officer is satisfied that any person is entitled to the beneficial ownership of any land he shall make an order admitting such ownership. (ii) If the Settlement Offioer is satisfied, as regards any land, that it is entirely free from any private rights or that the rights existing in or over it do not amount to fall ownership he shall make an order that the ownership of I the land is in the Government (iii.) If the Settlement Officer is satisfied that any person is entitled to any rights of the kind mentioned hereinafter in or over any land owned by the Government or any other person, or that the Government is entitled to any suoh right of a private nature in or over land owned by any person, that is to say (a) a right to cultivate by the natural flood of the river or by rain, (5) a right of pasture, (c) a right to forest produce, (f) any other beneficial rights or practice, the Settlement Officer shall make an order admitting the rights and defining the (iv.) The Settlement Offioer may, but it shall not be necessary for him, to reoord (a) a right of way. (A) a right to a watercourse or to the use of water. (v.) Where a claim to any right is admitted the Settlement Officer shall record the local limits within which such right may be ed the extent to which the benefit thereof may be leased sold or bartered and such other particulars as may be necessary to define the nature incidents and extent of the right. 7. —In adjudicating upon claims to land the following roles shall be followed : — (i.) The rules laid down for land commissions by the Title of Lands Ordinances shall be followed by the Settlement Officer, so far as they are not inconsistent with this Ordinance ; provided that a claimant shall not be barred under section 10 of the Title ofLand Ordinary 1899 on account of his not having presented a claim under that Ordinance, if he has during the five years preceding the presentation of his claim to the Settlement Officer exercised u of right any beneficial right in or over the land in question. (ii.) AU waste forest and unoccupied land shall be deemed to be the property of the Government until the contrary be proved. (iii.) In the oase of land which under the custemary methods in use with regard to the same is cultivable at irregular intervals, the fact that a person has cultivated the same for whatever period shall not by itself give him the absolute ownership of the land. (iv.)The exercise by any person of rights in or over one or more portions or panels of tad shall not be taken as a presumption In his favor as against the Government of ownership of any rights in or over any greater extent of land than that in or over which such rights were exercised. 8. —All rights admitted by the Settlement Officer and recorded in his order shall be presumed to be in gross and inheritable unless it is otherwise stated in the order. 9. —No right in or over any land which might have been made tho subject of a claim under this Ordinance other than a right of way or to a watercourse or the use of water shall be enforceable otherwise than in accordance with the provisions of this Ordinance. 10 In an enquiry under this Ordinance the Settlement Officer shall have the same powers as to summoning witnesses, and compelling their attendance, and administering oaths,and as to all matters of procedure as a Court under the Civil Justice Ordinance, and the procedure directed to be observed by Civil Courts shall be followed so far as applicable. EXPROPRIATION OF RIGHTS. 11. —Whenever a scheme or a provisional scheme has been approved for the artificial irrigation of any land which has been or may be declared to be Government tad under this Ordinance or such land is needed for building or for a public purpose the Governor General may compulsorily expropriate all private rights, if any, existing in or over such land. 12. —Whenever the Governor General has determined to make use if the powers conferred by the last section in respect of any particular land, a notice signed by him, containing a declaration to that effect, shall be published in the "Sudan Gazette." Such notice may ba added to the notice published under section 3 or may be a separate notice. It shall bo conclusive evidence that the land is needed for a purpose authorised by this Ordinance. 13. —The Settlement Officer shall thereupon proceed to expropriate all rights existing in or over such land in manner provided by the Land Acquisition Ordinance 1903 as hereinafter varied. 14. —For the purpose of such expropria- >n (i.) The Settlement Officer shall be deemed to be a Governor proceeding under the Land Acquisition Ordinance 1903. (ii.) The claimant shall be deemed to be person interested and appearing before him pursuance of a notice given under section 7 of that Aot, and the provisions of the preceding sections shall be deemed to have been complied with. (iii.) In the event of the Settlement Officer failing to come to a friendly agreement with the persons interested under section 9 the matter shall be settled by him as sole arbitrator and for that purpose he shall have the powers of and be subject to the like provisions as a Commission of Arbitration appointed under Section 12 of the Land Acquisition Ordinance 1903. (iv.) The Settlement Officer may award compensation in land or partly in land and partly in money. (v.) If the compensation consists of tad and the Government shall not be ready to give delivery of the some to the persons interested simultaneously with the taking over by the Government of rights expropriated from them the Settlement Officer shall award compensation by way of rent from the date when the Government enters into possession of such rights to the date when the Government delivers the tad or notifies its willing- ness to do so. (vi.) In determining the amount of compensation for rights which have no market value or of which the market value does not represent the full value to the person interested the arbitrator shall take into con-sideration in addition to the other matters mentioned in section 17 of the Land Acqui- tion Ordinance the profit derivable by the persons interested from the exercise of such rights. If the arbitrator shall award compen-sation in land the land shall be of such area and so selected that it shall be as profitable to the person interested as the right expropriated from him. (vit) If upon the expropriation of rights over "karn" or "bugr" tads artificially irrigated tad is awarded by way of compensation the tad so awarded shall not he less in area than one tenth of the "karn" or "bngr" tads over which such expropriated rights extend. Provided that upon the recommendation of the Settlement Officer the Governor General may dispense with this rule in particular t where such compensation would he in the opinion of the Settlement Officer undoubtedly APPEALS. 15.—(t) An appeal shall lie from any order made by a Settlement Officer under section 6 or 14 of this Ordinance to such civil judge or magistrate of the first class as the Governor General may appoint to hear appeals from such orders. (it) Bvery appeal under the last foregoing section must be presented within six months of the order. It shall be made by petition fa writing and may be delivered to the Settlement Officer who shall forward it without delay to the Officer competent to hear the same. (iii.) Every such appeal shall be heard in the manner prescribed for the hearing of appeals by the Court ot the Mudir order the Civil Justice Ordinance and the same fees shall be payable in respect thereof as on an appeal to the Court of the Mudir under that Ordinance and the order passed on such appeal shall be final RESTRAINT ON ALIENATION. 16.—Any rights over land declared to be Government land under this Ordinance and any tad granted by way of compensation under this Ordinance shall not ha A, mortgaged or charged except with the consent of the Governor of the Province and any alienation mortage charge or attempt to alienate mortgage or charge without such consent shall be void. Such consent shall not however be required to a lease of such rights or tad for a period n t exceeding three years or to their demise by will. RIGHTS up WAT AND WATERCOURSE. '.—A Settlement Offioer may from time to time with the previous consent of the Gover- of the Provinoe stop any public or private way nr watercourse. Provided that for the way or watercourse so stopped another way or watercourse which in the opinion of the Governor is equally convenient already exists or has been provided or constructed by the Settlement Officer.

div.head:
ISLAND OF CYPRUS.
LIMASOL AND PAPHOS.
div.p:
(FROM A CORRISPOMDINT.)
We now turn to the southern part of the island of Cyprus which is that nearest of access to Egypt, and the part which was is contact with civilisation from earliest times. The whole of the southern coast, as would be expected, is relaxing, more so even than Beyront and the plain of Sharon as far as 1 could judge, and the British military and civilians stationed at Limasol and Larnaca are not, I think, to be envied.lt is also a doubtful question as to what will be the effect upon these two ports of call of the new railway and the opening of the harbour of Famagusta. The Larnaca and Limasol steamship company is, I hear, making preparations to look after their interests. But it is diffioult to see how larnaca will survive, save as the telegraph station for the oapital, if its trade is largely diverted. The plaoe however can boast of great antiquity, as under the ancient name of Cftion it was probably one of the oldest Phoeniota settlements in the Medi-terranean, and is thought to he the Chittim of Numbers XXIV v. 24 and elsewhere. The roads from Nicosia to larnaca and to Limasol are of no particular interest, as they simply cross some bare foothills, the soil being of a chalky nature all over the low range to the southeast of the island. Bat some prettier scenery is met with about halfway between Nioosia and Limasol, where a conple of midday rest houses are to be found, dose to two successive mountain torrents. And the road is lined the rest of the way with groves of carob trees until the very sight of thrm hcomee monotony itself. There are plenty of vines higher on the hills, but save for some groves of very ancient fig and oiive trees near the sites of ancient towns and settlements, long since abandoned, the drive of 54 miles is disappointing. Moreover in summer the roads in Cypres everywhere full of white dost, save on the Troodos, so that a landau is the only suitable con- ia-oe. terestiog excursions. With the ancient Phoenician Amattins on the seashore seven miles to the East and the Argive city of Carium two miles to the west, there would be plenty for the antiquarian to discover had not Signor di Ceenola, the Amerioan Consul, dug only too suooessfolly in the latter, and the French removed from the former a oolossai stone vase and other treasures now in the Louvre. But coming down to crosadirg times the Englishman will like the hole, now converted into a native fa which Riohard I. married Queen Berongaxia. This site is in Limasol itself, while about seven miles off the road to Paphos, north of the salt lake and promontory beyond, lies the remains of the tower of Colossi, where the King and Queen spent their honeymoon. The castle tower lies in a jsplendid situation with a magnificent view from the roof. The place is kept by an Englishman, who, with his wife, is very hospitable to stangera. The arms containing the British lions, the Jerusalem cross, and the flour de lys are still visible on the eastern wall. Paphos is about 48 miles distent from Limisol by a hilly road with many zigzags up and down the pees, as yon arose ths numerous valleys with their mountain torrents that come down from Troodos. No Bible student and admirer of Paul and Barnabas would wish to miss those secluded spots which have such a history to tell There is a Palaoe-Paphos and a Neo Paphos, and they are distant ten miles the one from the other. The former was the great centre of Aphrodite worship, and the surf of the coast below still breaks into foam in fan- tastio shapes. The ancient temple lies perched upon a cliff now about two-thirds of a mile from the shore. And hither came that fastful throng year by year from many tads to do node worship to the goddess. Doubtless this is what cansed Neo-Paphos with its tiny harbom to become the site of apro-oonsnlate fa apostolio times. But now, save for the commissioner's yacht and a few small fishing craft with the remains of a mediicval castle as a breakwater to the bay, nothing except masses of stores and here and there a Corinthian pillar remains to mark the scene where Sergius Paulus was converted to the Christian faith. They show the visitor two pillars place to a Byzantine church where they say St Paul was i beaten. But it is possible from tradition to - complete the story. For we are told that the statue of the goddess was overthrown by the prayers of Barnabas. And there seems no ' room for doubting that it was the work of this apostle that led to the overthrow of this hideous form of worship. Now, perhaps, we see ' why he was so anxious to return to his native He felt he had a work of patriotism to do, to rid his country of this truly international curse, and he succeeded. Seriously enough, I spent the Eastern and Western day of St. Barnabes at Famagusta, close to traditional site of his tomb, and the day I returned from Saphos was a public holiday, I was informed, called Aphrodites day.

div.head: THE COMING COTTON SEASON
div.p: Forecasts of the new season an seldom more difficult than when the crops are specially subject to the influence of the weather far some time to come. Nevertheless it is possible to sketch the broad features and probabilities of the new season on what is already known of the old. Moreover, fa one respect at least, the new ' i less uncertain than any ofitsim- predetoaeon. Spinners are already supplied with orders for months forward, and they are covered by contents for cotton. A period of good business—longer or shorter—is thus assured. Nor is any reason yet apparent which should prevent the giving of farther orders sa the old contracts expire. Harvests generally have been goofl fa most parts of the worrid, the chances of Improvement fa basinets now that peace is declared good, and from none of the large foreign markets need less than an average or fall demand be looked for. Thereis likely to be more rather than less activity in the home trade, and Lancashire is pnttiog up Dew mills to meet the demand from all quarters. When all of them are fully at work the actual consumption may rise to 60,000 Amerioan bales a week instead of of 65,000 to 56,000 estimated for the past twelve months. If these views may be partly modified by the knowledge that large stocks of goods are now held fa some of the Eastern may nevertheless prove broadly prioes this year—namely, a good business, the holding back of ootton by planters, sod speculative activity. Only the development of tbe season's business and the fortunes of the crop can decide thecorrect Unless cotton be too dear and prices in Manchester consequently too high, a fall business with the world is likely to be done, end in this sense — namely, fa a reasonable security for a good season's demand the entry into the new season shows lees uncertainty then naual. On the question of the price of cotton, the position at the present moment is less easy to define. The crop has to face the risk of heat (although the period of great heat is now be nearly over) and frost Information about the orop has been so much affected by the propaganda of speculators and by the Bureau irregularities that its actual position is more obscure than usual. Broadly, it may be said that if the Barcau be trusted the crop mast be small, and that if the general reports received imaesol, however, is a centre of many in- ky merchants .ffpm their correspondents be question, but on the whob the probabilities wonld seem to point to a bwer range of prioes for 1905-6. It is also not improbable that the comfag season may show rather large fluctuations. The new orop is coming down to the ports, where largo supplies exist, and it has to he shipped to Europe, where stooks of some magnitude are in the hands of merohants and spinners. These oiroumstanoea may possibly prodnoe a temporary depression of a notable kind, but it most in that case be dearly remembered that any decline going below the onltivator's costof growing ootton, should thsrt occur, carries with it the certainty of redooed acreage and careless cultivation of the following orop and of a consequent rebound. Appearances point to Lancashire's consnmption being somewhat larger this season than last, but the takings will not be so large. The shipments to Great Britain, which have been ronndly 4,100,000 fa the past season, may not be so large during that opon which we are now entering, but the Liverpool stock is likely to be larger and may even reaoh considerable figures. U is also quite possible that the new season may at some time show a long period of small spot markets whenever the spinner falls hack on his reserve stooks of ootton. With regard to the Indian orop it ia at present impossible to say much. The prospeots are enoouragfag in those districts which grow the principal varieties of ootton. Shortage of rainfall has been reported fa the Punjaub and fa Rsjputaoa, but these districts, although they grow some Bengal ootton, are principally known for their wheat production. Elsewhere the reins have bean sufficient or plentiful, and fa Gujarat exoMsive. The tat Indian crop was large tfceaoreerfthe pemt owp h tamMd, and nothing is at present known which should make the yield smaller than the last Europe during the past season has bought far less Surat than daring the preoeding season, but the Indian and Japanese mills have been busy. The Indian holders of ootton have followed the Amerioan policy of refusing low prioes and have oarried over an unusually heavy stock into the new season. It remains to be seen bow far suoh a policy will answer their purpose. From Egypt the reports are distinctly good. Thera is saffioitnt water for the cultivator, although the volume of water fa the Nile has been only moderately full. A large acreage has been planted, and prospeots are at present flattering. The crop bos yet to fear autumn fogs, but if it escape these, or unless they are unusually injurious, a lull or large crop is to be looked for. It mould therefore appear that at the present moment the prospeots of all the principal crops an of a nature to encourage hopes of oootinned abundanoe. Even if the American orop should prove disappointing the large surplus earned over from the late orop will avert any real danger of shortage. Crops and surpluses together ought to supply every requirement of the spindles of the world for 1905-6. Appearances, therefore, are in favor of another year's healthy trade, and it can only be hoped that as the season pisses it may prove as good and as profitable for Lancashire as the season 1904-5. in Bogtieh will be resumed fa the Church of the American Mission Cairo, on the evening of the 17th of theonrrent month. div.head: Egyptian Delta Light Railways Co., Limited.
div.p: Connections made with the most important trains of the State Railway in the Provinces of Behera, Gharbieh, Dakahlieh Charkieh and Galioubieh.Through service for goods between all stations of the Company andover 100 principal stations of the State Railway in Upper and Lower Egypt. Goods may also be through-booked from or to any station on Helouan Railway. The Company has 70 stations opened for public Telegraph Service in conjunction with all offices of the Government Telegraph Department.For time tables, tariffs and information apply to the offices at Cairo, Alexandria Damanhour, Tantah or Zagazig. 21416 31-12.905
